segment.source: ScanState Syntax (Windows 10)
segment.target: ScanState Syntax (Windows 10)

segment.source: ScanState Syntax
segment.target: ScanState Syntax

segment.source: ScanState Syntax
segment.target: ScanState Syntax

segment.source: The ScanState command is used with the User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0 to scan the source computer, collect the files and settings, and create a store.
segment.target: The ScanState command is used with the User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0 to scan the source computer, collect the files and settings, and create a store.

segment.source: In This Topic
segment.target: In This Topic

segment.source: Before You Begin
segment.target: Before You Begin

segment.source: Syntax
segment.target: Syntax

segment.source: Storage Options
segment.target: Storage Options

segment.source: Migration Rule Options
segment.target: Migration Rule Options

segment.source: Monitoring Options
segment.target: Monitoring Options

segment.source: User Options
segment.target: User Options

segment.source: Encrypted File Options
segment.target: Encrypted File Options

segment.source: Incompatible Command-Line Options
segment.target: Incompatible Command-Line Options

segment.source: Before You Begin
segment.target: Before You Begin

segment.source: Before you run the ScanState command, note the following:
segment.target: Before you run the ScanState command, note the following:

segment.source: To ensure that all operating system settings migrate, in most cases you must run the ScanState commands in administrator mode from an account with administrative credentials.
segment.target: To ensure that all operating system settings migrate, in most cases you must run the ScanState commands in administrator mode from an account with administrative credentials.

segment.source: If you encrypt the migration store, you will be required to enter an encryption key or a path to a file containing the encryption key.
segment.target: If you encrypt the migration store, you will be required to enter an encryption key or a path to a file containing the encryption key.

segment.source: Be sure to make note of the key or the key file location, because this information is not kept anywhere in the migration store.
segment.target: Be sure to make note of the key or the key file location, because this information is not kept anywhere in the migration store.

segment.source: You will need this information when you run the LoadState command to decrypt the migration store, or if you need to run the recovery utility.
segment.target: You will need this information when you run the LoadState command to decrypt the migration store, or if you need to run the recovery utility.

segment.source: An incorrect or missing key or key file results in an error message.
segment.target: An incorrect or missing key or key file results in an error message.

segment.source: For information about software requirements for running the ScanState command, see USMT Requirements.
segment.target: For information about software requirements for running the ScanState command, see USMT Requirements.

segment.source: Unless otherwise noted, you can use each option only once when running a tool on the command line.
segment.target: Unless otherwise noted, you can use each option only once when running a tool on the command line.

segment.source: You can gather domain accounts without the source computer having domain controller access.
segment.target: You can gather domain accounts without the source computer having domain controller access.

segment.source: This functionality is available without any additional configuration.
segment.target: This functionality is available without any additional configuration.

segment.source: The Incompatible Command-Line Options table lists which options you can use together and which command-line options are incompatible.
segment.target: The Incompatible Command-Line Options table lists which options you can use together and which command-line options are incompatible.

segment.source: The directory location where you save the migration store will be excluded from the scan.
segment.target: The directory location where you save the migration store will be excluded from the scan.

segment.source: For example, if you save the migration store to the root of the D drive, the D drive and all of its subdirectories will be excluded from the scan.
segment.target: For example, if you save the migration store to the root of the D drive, the D drive and all of its subdirectories will be excluded from the scan.

segment.source: Syntax
segment.target: Syntax

segment.source: This section explains the syntax and usage of the ScanState command-line options.
segment.target: This section explains the syntax and usage of the ScanState command-line options.

segment.source: The options can be specified in any order.
segment.target: The options can be specified in any order.

segment.source: If the option contains a parameter, you can use either a colon or a space separator.
segment.target: If the option contains a parameter, you can use either a colon or a space separator.

segment.source: The ScanState command's syntax is:
segment.target: The ScanState command's syntax is:

segment.source: scanstate StorePath/apps/ppkg:FileName/i:PathFileName/o/v:VerbosityLevel/nocompress/localonly/encrypt /key:KeyString|/keyfile:PathFileName/l:PathFileName/progress:PathFileName/r:TimesToRetry/w:SecondsBeforeRetry/c/p/all/ui:DomainNameComputerNameUserName/ue:DomainNameComputerNameUserName/uel:NumberOfDaysYYYY/MM/DD|0/efs:abort|skip|decryptcopy|copyraw/genconfig:PathFileName/config:PathFileName/?|help
segment.target: scanstate StorePath/apps/ppkg:FileName/i:PathFileName/o/v:VerbosityLevel/nocompress/localonly/encrypt /key:KeyString|/keyfile:PathFileName/l:PathFileName/progress:PathFileName/r:TimesToRetry/w:SecondsBeforeRetry/c/p/all/ui:DomainNameComputerNameUserName/ue:DomainNameComputerNameUserName/uel:NumberOfDaysYYYY/MM/DD|0/efs:abort|skip|decryptcopy|copyraw/genconfig:PathFileName/config:PathFileName/?|help

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: To create a Config.xml file in the current directory, use:
segment.target: To create a Config.xml file in the current directory, use:

segment.source: To create an encrypted store using the Config.xml file and the default migration .xml files, use:
segment.target: To create an encrypted store using the Config.xml file and the default migration .xml files, use:

segment.source: Storage Options
segment.target: Storage Options

segment.source: Command-Line Option
segment.target: Command-Line Option

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: StorePath
segment.target: StorePath

segment.source: Indicates a folder where files and settings will be saved.
segment.target: Indicates a folder where files and settings will be saved.

segment.source: Note that StorePath cannot be c:\.
segment.target: Note that StorePath cannot be c:\.

segment.source: You must specify the StorePath option in the ScanState command, except when using the /genconfig option.
segment.target: You must specify the StorePath option in the ScanState command, except when using the /genconfig option.

segment.source: You cannot specify more than one StorePath location.
segment.target: You cannot specify more than one StorePath location.

segment.source: /apps
segment.target: /apps

segment.source: Scans the image for apps and includes them and their associated registry settings.
segment.target: Scans the image for apps and includes them and their associated registry settings.

segment.source: /ppkg [FileName]
segment.target: /ppkg [FileName]

segment.source: Exports to a specific file location.
segment.target: Exports to a specific file location.

segment.source: /o
segment.target: /o

segment.source: Required to overwrite any existing data in the migration store or Config.xml file.
segment.target: Required to overwrite any existing data in the migration store or Config.xml file.

segment.source: If not specified, the ScanState command will fail if the migration store already contains data.
segment.target: If not specified, the ScanState command will fail if the migration store already contains data.

segment.source: You cannot use this option more than once on a command line.
segment.target: You cannot use this option more than once on a command line.

segment.source: /vsc
segment.target: /vsc

segment.source: This option enables the volume shadow-copy service to migrate files that are locked or in use.
segment.target: This option enables the volume shadow-copy service to migrate files that are locked or in use.

segment.source: This command-line option eliminates most file-locking errors that are typically encountered by the ErrorControl section.
segment.target: This command-line option eliminates most file-locking errors that are typically encountered by the ErrorControl section.

segment.source: This option can be used only with the ScanState executable file and cannot be combined with the /hardlink option.
segment.target: This option can be used only with the ScanState executable file and cannot be combined with the /hardlink option.

segment.source: /hardlink
segment.target: /hardlink

segment.source: Enables the creation of a hard-link migration store at the specified location.
segment.target: Enables the creation of a hard-link migration store at the specified location.

segment.source: The /nocompress option must be specified with the /hardlink option.
segment.target: The /nocompress option must be specified with the /hardlink option.

segment.source: /encrypt [{/key:KeyString/keyfile:file]}
segment.target: /encrypt [{/key:KeyString/keyfile:file]}

segment.source: Encrypts the store with the specified key.
segment.target: Encrypts the store with the specified key.

segment.source: Encryption is disabled by default.
segment.target: Encryption is disabled by default.

segment.source: With this option, you will need to specify the encryption key in one of the following ways:
segment.target: With this option, you will need to specify the encryption key in one of the following ways:

segment.source: /key:KeyString specifies the encryption key.
segment.target: /key:KeyString specifies the encryption key.

segment.source: If there is a space in KeyString, you will need to surround KeyString with quotation marks.
segment.target: If there is a space in KeyString, you will need to surround KeyString with quotation marks.

segment.source: /keyfile:FilePathAndName specifies a text (.txt) file that contains the encryption key.
segment.target: /keyfile:FilePathAndName specifies a text (.txt) file that contains the encryption key.

segment.source: We recommend that KeyString be at least eight characters long, but it cannot exceed 256 characters.
segment.target: We recommend that KeyString be at least eight characters long, but it cannot exceed 256 characters.

segment.source: The /key and /keyfile options cannot be used on the same command line.
segment.target: The /key and /keyfile options cannot be used on the same command line.

segment.source: The /encrypt and /nocompress options cannot be used on the same command line.
segment.target: The /encrypt and /nocompress options cannot be used on the same command line.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You should use caution with this option, because anyone who has access to the ScanState command-line script will also have access to the encryption key.
segment.target: You should use caution with this option, because anyone who has access to the ScanState command-line script will also have access to the encryption key.

segment.source: The following example shows the ScanState command and the /key option:
segment.target: The following example shows the ScanState command and the /key option:

segment.source: /encrypt:EncryptionStrength
segment.target: /encrypt:EncryptionStrength

segment.source: The /encrypt option accepts a command-line parameter to define the encryption strength to be used for encryption of the migration store.
segment.target: The /encrypt option accepts a command-line parameter to define the encryption strength to be used for encryption of the migration store.

segment.source: For more information about supported encryption algorithms, see Migration Store Encryption.
segment.target: For more information about supported encryption algorithms, see Migration Store Encryption.

segment.source: /nocompress
segment.target: /nocompress

segment.source: Disables compression of data and saves the files to a hidden folder named File at StorePath\USMT.
segment.target: Disables compression of data and saves the files to a hidden folder named File at StorePath\USMT.

segment.source: Compression is enabled by default.
segment.target: Compression is enabled by default.

segment.source: Combining the /nocompress option with the /hardlink option generates a hard-link migration store.
segment.target: Combining the /nocompress option with the /hardlink option generates a hard-link migration store.

segment.source: You can use the uncompressed store to view what USMT stored, troubleshoot a problem, or run an antivirus utility against the files.
segment.target: You can use the uncompressed store to view what USMT stored, troubleshoot a problem, or run an antivirus utility against the files.

segment.source: You should use this option only in testing environments, because we recommend that you use a compressed store during your actual migration, unless you are combining the /nocompress option with the /hardlink option.
segment.target: You should use this option only in testing environments, because we recommend that you use a compressed store during your actual migration, unless you are combining the /nocompress option with the /hardlink option.

segment.source: The /nocompress and /encrypt options cannot be used together in one statement on the command line.
segment.target: The /nocompress and /encrypt options cannot be used together in one statement on the command line.

segment.source: However, if you do choose to migrate an uncompressed store, the LoadState command will migrate each file directly from the store to the correct location on the destination computer without a temporary location.
segment.target: However, if you do choose to migrate an uncompressed store, the LoadState command will migrate each file directly from the store to the correct location on the destination computer without a temporary location.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Run the ScanState Command on an Offline Windows System
segment.target: Run the ScanState Command on an Offline Windows System

segment.source: You can run the ScanState command in Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE).
segment.target: You can run the ScanState command in Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE).

segment.source: In addition, USMT supports migrations from previous installations of Windows contained in Windows.old directories.
segment.target: In addition, USMT supports migrations from previous installations of Windows contained in Windows.old directories.

segment.source: The offline directory can be a Windows directory when you run the ScanState command in WinPE or a Windows.old directory when you run the ScanState command in Windows.
segment.target: The offline directory can be a Windows directory when you run the ScanState command in WinPE or a Windows.old directory when you run the ScanState command in Windows.

segment.source: There are several benefits to running the ScanState command on an offline Windows image, including:
segment.target: There are several benefits to running the ScanState command on an offline Windows image, including:

segment.source: Improved Performance.
segment.target: Improved Performance.

segment.source: Because WinPE is a thin operating system, there are fewer running services.
segment.target: Because WinPE is a thin operating system, there are fewer running services.

segment.source: In this environment, the ScanState command has more access to the local hardware resources, enabling ScanState to perform migration operations more quickly.
segment.target: In this environment, the ScanState command has more access to the local hardware resources, enabling ScanState to perform migration operations more quickly.

segment.source: Simplified end to end deployment process.
segment.target: Simplified end to end deployment process.

segment.source: Migrating data from Windows.old simplifies the end-to-end deployment process by enabling the migration process to occur after the new operating system is installed.
segment.target: Migrating data from Windows.old simplifies the end-to-end deployment process by enabling the migration process to occur after the new operating system is installed.

segment.source: Improved success of migration.
segment.target: Improved success of migration.

segment.source: The migration success rate is increased because files will not be locked for editing while offline, and because WinPE provides administrator access to files in the offline Windows file system, eliminating the need for administrator-level access to the online system.
segment.target: The migration success rate is increased because files will not be locked for editing while offline, and because WinPE provides administrator access to files in the offline Windows file system, eliminating the need for administrator-level access to the online system.

segment.source: Ability to recover an unbootable computer.
segment.target: Ability to recover an unbootable computer.

segment.source: It might be possible to recover and migrate data from an unbootable computer.
segment.target: It might be possible to recover and migrate data from an unbootable computer.

segment.source: Offline Migration Options
segment.target: Offline Migration Options

segment.source: Command-Line Option
segment.target: Command-Line Option

segment.source: Definition
segment.target: Definition

segment.source: /offline:path to an offline.xml file
segment.target: /offline:path to an offline.xml file

segment.source: This option is used to define a path to an offline .xml file that might specify other offline migration options, for example, an offline Windows directory or any domain or folder redirection required in your migration.
segment.target: This option is used to define a path to an offline .xml file that might specify other offline migration options, for example, an offline Windows directory or any domain or folder redirection required in your migration.

segment.source: /offlinewindir:path to a Windows directory
segment.target: /offlinewindir:path to a Windows directory

segment.source: This option specifies the offline Windows directory that the ScanState command gathers user state from.
segment.target: This option specifies the offline Windows directory that the ScanState command gathers user state from.

segment.source: The offline directory can be Windows.old when you run the ScanState command in Windows or a Windows directory when you run the ScanState command in WinPE.
segment.target: The offline directory can be Windows.old when you run the ScanState command in Windows or a Windows directory when you run the ScanState command in WinPE.

segment.source: /offlinewinold:Windows.old directory
segment.target: /offlinewinold:Windows.old directory

segment.source: This command-line option enables the offline migration mode and starts the migration from the location specified.
segment.target: This command-line option enables the offline migration mode and starts the migration from the location specified.

segment.source: It is only intended to be used in Windows.old migration scenarios, where the migration is occurring from a Windows.old directory.
segment.target: It is only intended to be used in Windows.old migration scenarios, where the migration is occurring from a Windows.old directory.

segment.source: Migration Rule Options
segment.target: Migration Rule Options

segment.source: USMT provides the following options to specify what files you want to migrate.
segment.target: USMT provides the following options to specify what files you want to migrate.

segment.source: Command-Line Option
segment.target: Command-Line Option

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: /i:[PathFileName
segment.target: /i:[PathFileName

segment.source: (include)
segment.target: (include)

segment.source: Specifies an .xml file that contains rules that define what user, application or system state to migrate.
segment.target: Specifies an .xml file that contains rules that define what user, application or system state to migrate.

segment.source: You can specify this option multiple times to include all of your .xml files (MigApp.xml, MigDocs.xml, and any custom .xml files that you create).
segment.target: You can specify this option multiple times to include all of your .xml files (MigApp.xml, MigDocs.xml, and any custom .xml files that you create).

segment.source: Path can be either a relative or full path.
segment.target: Path can be either a relative or full path.

segment.source: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName must be located in the current directory.
segment.target: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName must be located in the current directory.

segment.source: For more information about which files to specify, see the XML Files section of the Frequently Asked Questions topic.
segment.target: For more information about which files to specify, see the XML Files section of the Frequently Asked Questions topic.

segment.source: /genconfig:[PathFileName
segment.target: /genconfig:[PathFileName

segment.source: (Generate Config.xml)
segment.target: (Generate Config.xml)

segment.source: Generates the optional Config.xml file, but does not create a migration store.
segment.target: Generates the optional Config.xml file, but does not create a migration store.

segment.source: To ensure that this file contains every component, application and setting that can be migrated, you should create this file on a source computer that contains all the components, applications and settings that will be present on the destination computers.
segment.target: To ensure that this file contains every component, application and setting that can be migrated, you should create this file on a source computer that contains all the components, applications and settings that will be present on the destination computers.

segment.source: In addition, you should specify the other migration .xml files, using the /i option, when you specify this option.
segment.target: In addition, you should specify the other migration .xml files, using the /i option, when you specify this option.

segment.source: After you create this file, you will need to make use of it with the ScanState command using the /config option.
segment.target: After you create this file, you will need to make use of it with the ScanState command using the /config option.

segment.source: The only options that you can specify with this option are the /i, /v, and /l options.
segment.target: The only options that you can specify with this option are the /i, /v, and /l options.

segment.source: You cannot specify StorePath, because the /genconfig option does not create a store.
segment.target: You cannot specify StorePath, because the /genconfig option does not create a store.

segment.source: Path can be either a relative or full path.
segment.target: Path can be either a relative or full path.

segment.source: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName will be created in the current directory.
segment.target: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName will be created in the current directory.

segment.source: Examples:
segment.target: Examples:

segment.source: The following example creates a Config.xml file in the current directory:
segment.target: The following example creates a Config.xml file in the current directory:

segment.source: /config:[Path\]FileName
segment.target: /config:[Path\]FileName

segment.source: Specifies the Config.xml file that the ScanState command should use to create the store.
segment.target: Specifies the Config.xml file that the ScanState command should use to create the store.

segment.source: You cannot use this option more than once on the command line.
segment.target: You cannot use this option more than once on the command line.

segment.source: Path can be either a relative or full path.
segment.target: Path can be either a relative or full path.

segment.source: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName must be located in the current directory.
segment.target: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName must be located in the current directory.

segment.source: The following example creates a store using the Config.xml file, MigDocs.xml, and MigApp.xml files:
segment.target: The following example creates a store using the Config.xml file, MigDocs.xml, and MigApp.xml files:

segment.source: The following example migrates the files and settings to the destination computer using the Config.xml, MigDocs.xml, and MigApp.xml files:
segment.target: The following example migrates the files and settings to the destination computer using the Config.xml, MigDocs.xml, and MigApp.xml files:

segment.source: /auto:path to script files
segment.target: /auto:path to script files

segment.source: This option enables you to specify the location of the default .xml files and then begin the migration.
segment.target: This option enables you to specify the location of the default .xml files and then begin the migration.

segment.source: If no path is specified, USMT will reference the directory where the USMT binaries are located.
segment.target: If no path is specified, USMT will reference the directory where the USMT binaries are located.

segment.source: The /auto option has the same effect as using the following options: /i:MigDocs.xml/i:MigApp.xml /v:5.
segment.target: The /auto option has the same effect as using the following options: /i:MigDocs.xml/i:MigApp.xml /v:5.

segment.source: /genmigxml:path to a file
segment.target: /genmigxml:path to a file

segment.source: This option specifies that the ScanState command should use the document finder to create and export an .xml file that defines how to migrate all of the files on the computer on which the ScanState command is running.
segment.target: This option specifies that the ScanState command should use the document finder to create and export an .xml file that defines how to migrate all of the files on the computer on which the ScanState command is running.

segment.source: /targetwindows8
segment.target: /targetwindows8

segment.source: Optimizes Scanstate.exe when using USMT 10.0 to migrate a user state to Windows 8 or Windows 8.1 instead of Windows 10.
segment.target: Optimizes Scanstate.exe when using USMT 10.0 to migrate a user state to Windows 8 or Windows 8.1 instead of Windows 10.

segment.source: You should use this command line option in the following scenarios:
segment.target: You should use this command line option in the following scenarios:

segment.source: To create a Config.xml file by using the /genconfig option.
segment.target: To create a Config.xml file by using the /genconfig option.

segment.source: Using the /targetwindows8 option optimizes the Config.xml file so that it only contains components that relate to Windows 8 or Windows 8.1.
segment.target: Using the /targetwindows8 option optimizes the Config.xml file so that it only contains components that relate to Windows 8 or Windows 8.1.

segment.source: To create a migration store.
segment.target: To create a migration store.

segment.source: Using the /targetwindows8 option ensures that the ScanState tool gathers the correct set of operating system settings.
segment.target: Using the /targetwindows8 option ensures that the ScanState tool gathers the correct set of operating system settings.

segment.source: Without the /targetwindows8 command-line option, some settings can be lost during the migration.
segment.target: Without the /targetwindows8 command-line option, some settings can be lost during the migration.

segment.source: /targetwindows7
segment.target: /targetwindows7

segment.source: Optimizes Scanstate.exe when using USMT 10.0 to migrate a user state to Windows 7 instead of Windows 10.
segment.target: Optimizes Scanstate.exe when using USMT 10.0 to migrate a user state to Windows 7 instead of Windows 10.

segment.source: You should use this command line option in the following scenarios:
segment.target: You should use this command line option in the following scenarios:

segment.source: To create a Config.xml file by using the /genconfig option.
segment.target: To create a Config.xml file by using the /genconfig option.

segment.source: Using the /targetwindows7 option optimizes the Config.xml file so that it only contains components that relate to Windows 7.
segment.target: Using the /targetwindows7 option optimizes the Config.xml file so that it only contains components that relate to Windows 7.

segment.source: To create a migration store.
segment.target: To create a migration store.

segment.source: Using the /targetwindows7 option ensures that the ScanState tool gathers the correct set of operating system settings.
segment.target: Using the /targetwindows7 option ensures that the ScanState tool gathers the correct set of operating system settings.

segment.source: Without the /targetwindows7 command-line option, some settings can be lost during the migration.
segment.target: Without the /targetwindows7 command-line option, some settings can be lost during the migration.

segment.source: /localonly
segment.target: /localonly

segment.source: Migrates only files that are stored on the local computer, regardless of the rules in the .xml files that you specify on the command line.
segment.target: Migrates only files that are stored on the local computer, regardless of the rules in the .xml files that you specify on the command line.

segment.source: You should use this option when you want to exclude the data from removable drives on the source computer, such as USB flash drives (UFDs), some external hard drives, and so on, and when there are network drives mapped on the source computer.
segment.target: You should use this option when you want to exclude the data from removable drives on the source computer, such as USB flash drives (UFDs), some external hard drives, and so on, and when there are network drives mapped on the source computer.

segment.source: If the /localonly option is not specified, then the ScanState command will copy files from these removable or network drives into the store.
segment.target: If the /localonly option is not specified, then the ScanState command will copy files from these removable or network drives into the store.

segment.source: Anything that is not considered a fixed drive by the OS will be excluded by /localonly.
segment.target: Anything that is not considered a fixed drive by the OS will be excluded by /localonly.

segment.source: In some cases large external hard drives are considered fixed drives.
segment.target: In some cases large external hard drives are considered fixed drives.

segment.source: These drives can be explicitly excluded from migration by using a custom.xml file.
segment.target: These drives can be explicitly excluded from migration by using a custom.xml file.

segment.source: For more information about how to exclude all files on a specific drive, see Exclude Files and Settings.
segment.target: For more information about how to exclude all files on a specific drive, see Exclude Files and Settings.

segment.source: The /localonly command-line option includes or excludes data in the migration as identified in the following table:
segment.target: The /localonly command-line option includes or excludes data in the migration as identified in the following table:

segment.source: Drive type
segment.target: Drive type

segment.source: Behavior with /localonly
segment.target: Behavior with /localonly

segment.source: Removable drives such as a USB flash drive
segment.target: Removable drives such as a USB flash drive

segment.source: Excluded
segment.target: Excluded

segment.source: Network drives
segment.target: Network drives

segment.source: Excluded
segment.target: Excluded

segment.source: Fixed drives
segment.target: Fixed drives

segment.source: Included
segment.target: Included

segment.source: Monitoring Options
segment.target: Monitoring Options

segment.source: USMT provides several options that you can use to analyze problems that occur during migration.
segment.target: USMT provides several options that you can use to analyze problems that occur during migration.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The ScanState log is created by default, but you can specify the name and location of the log with the /l option.
segment.target: The ScanState log is created by default, but you can specify the name and location of the log with the /l option.

segment.source: Command-Line Option
segment.target: Command-Line Option

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: /listfiles:FileName
segment.target: /listfiles:FileName

segment.source: You can use the /listfiles command-line option with the ScanState command to generate a text file that lists all of the files included in the migration.
segment.target: You can use the /listfiles command-line option with the ScanState command to generate a text file that lists all of the files included in the migration.

segment.source: /l:[PathFileName
segment.target: /l:[PathFileName

segment.source: Specifies the location and name of the ScanState log.
segment.target: Specifies the location and name of the ScanState log.

segment.source: You cannot store any of the log files in StorePath.
segment.target: You cannot store any of the log files in StorePath.

segment.source: Path can be either a relative or full path.
segment.target: Path can be either a relative or full path.

segment.source: If you do not specify the Path variable, then the log will be created in the current directory.
segment.target: If you do not specify the Path variable, then the log will be created in the current directory.

segment.source: You can use the /v option to adjust the amount of output.
segment.target: You can use the /v option to adjust the amount of output.

segment.source: If you run the ScanState or LoadState commands from a shared network resource, you must specify this option or USMT will fail with the following error: USMT was unable to create the log file(s).
segment.target: If you run the ScanState or LoadState commands from a shared network resource, you must specify this option or USMT will fail with the following error: USMT was unable to create the log file(s).

segment.source: To fix this issue, use the /l:scan.log command.
segment.target: To fix this issue, use the /l:scan.log command.

segment.source: /v:VerbosityLevel
segment.target: /v:VerbosityLevel

segment.source: (Verbosity)
segment.target: (Verbosity)

segment.source: Enables verbose output in the ScanState log file.
segment.target: Enables verbose output in the ScanState log file.

segment.source: The default value is 0.
segment.target: The default value is 0.

segment.source: You can set the VerbosityLevel to one of the following levels:
segment.target: You can set the VerbosityLevel to one of the following levels:

segment.source: Level
segment.target: Level

segment.source: Explanation
segment.target: Explanation

segment.source: Only the default errors and warnings are enabled.
segment.target: Only the default errors and warnings are enabled.

segment.source: Enables verbose output.
segment.target: Enables verbose output.

segment.source: Enables error and status output.
segment.target: Enables error and status output.

segment.source: Enables verbose and status output.
segment.target: Enables verbose and status output.

segment.source: Enables error output to a debugger.
segment.target: Enables error output to a debugger.

segment.source: Enables verbose output to a debugger.
segment.target: Enables verbose output to a debugger.

segment.source: Enables error and status output to a debugger.
segment.target: Enables error and status output to a debugger.

segment.source: Enables verbose, status, and debugger output.
segment.target: Enables verbose, status, and debugger output.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: progress:[Path\]FileName
segment.target: progress:[Path\]FileName

segment.source: Creates the optional progress log.
segment.target: Creates the optional progress log.

segment.source: You cannot store any of the log files in StorePath.
segment.target: You cannot store any of the log files in StorePath.

segment.source: Path can be either a relative or full path.
segment.target: Path can be either a relative or full path.

segment.source: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName will be created in the current directory.
segment.target: If you do not specify the Path variable, then FileName will be created in the current directory.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: /c
segment.target: /c

segment.source: When this option is specified, the ScanState command will continue to run, even if non-fatal errors occur.
segment.target: When this option is specified, the ScanState command will continue to run, even if non-fatal errors occur.

segment.source: Any files or settings that cause an error are logged in the progress log.
segment.target: Any files or settings that cause an error are logged in the progress log.

segment.source: For example, if there is a large file that will not fit in the store, the ScanState command will log an error and continue with the migration.
segment.target: For example, if there is a large file that will not fit in the store, the ScanState command will log an error and continue with the migration.

segment.source: In addition, if a file is open or in use by an application, USMT may not be able to migrate the file and will log an error.
segment.target: In addition, if a file is open or in use by an application, USMT may not be able to migrate the file and will log an error.

segment.source: Without the /c option, the ScanState command will exit on the first error.
segment.target: Without the /c option, the ScanState command will exit on the first error.

segment.source: You can use the new ErrorControl section in the Config.xml file to specify which file or registry read/write errors can be safely ignored and which might cause the migration to fail.
segment.target: You can use the new ErrorControl section in the Config.xml file to specify which file or registry read/write errors can be safely ignored and which might cause the migration to fail.

segment.source: This enables the /c command-line option to safely skip all input/output (I/O) errors in your environment.
segment.target: This enables the /c command-line option to safely skip all input/output (I/O) errors in your environment.

segment.source: In addition, the /genconfig option now generates a sample ErrorControl section that is enabled by specifying error messages and desired behaviors in the Config.xml file.
segment.target: In addition, the /genconfig option now generates a sample ErrorControl section that is enabled by specifying error messages and desired behaviors in the Config.xml file.

segment.source: /r:TimesToRetry
segment.target: /r:TimesToRetry

segment.source: (Retry)
segment.target: (Retry)

segment.source: Specifies the number of times to retry when an error occurs while saving the user state to a server.
segment.target: Specifies the number of times to retry when an error occurs while saving the user state to a server.

segment.source: The default is three times.
segment.target: The default is three times.

segment.source: This option is useful in environments where network connectivity is not reliable.
segment.target: This option is useful in environments where network connectivity is not reliable.

segment.source: While storing the user state, the /r option will not be able to recover data that is lost due to a network-hardware failure, such as a faulty or disconnected network cable, or when a virtual private network (VPN) connection fails.
segment.target: While storing the user state, the /r option will not be able to recover data that is lost due to a network-hardware failure, such as a faulty or disconnected network cable, or when a virtual private network (VPN) connection fails.

segment.source: The retry option is intended for large, busy networks where connectivity is satisfactory, but communication latency is a problem.
segment.target: The retry option is intended for large, busy networks where connectivity is satisfactory, but communication latency is a problem.

segment.source: /w:SecondsBeforeRetry
segment.target: /w:SecondsBeforeRetry

segment.source: (Wait)
segment.target: (Wait)

segment.source: Specifies the time to wait, in seconds, before retrying a network file operation.
segment.target: Specifies the time to wait, in seconds, before retrying a network file operation.

segment.source: The default is 1 second.
segment.target: The default is 1 second.

segment.source: /p:pathToFile
segment.target: /p:pathToFile

segment.source: When the ScanState command runs, it will create an .xml file in the path specified.
segment.target: When the ScanState command runs, it will create an .xml file in the path specified.

segment.source: This .xml file includes improved space estimations for the migration store.
segment.target: This .xml file includes improved space estimations for the migration store.

segment.source: The following example shows how to create this .xml file:
segment.target: The following example shows how to create this .xml file:

segment.source: For more information, see Estimate Migration Store Size.
segment.target: For more information, see Estimate Migration Store Size.

segment.source: To preserve the functionality of existing applications or scripts that require the previous behavior of USMT, you can use the /p option, without specifying pathtoafile, in USMT.
segment.target: To preserve the functionality of existing applications or scripts that require the previous behavior of USMT, you can use the /p option, without specifying pathtoafile, in USMT.

segment.source: If you specify only the /p option, the storage space estimations are created in the same manner as with USMT3.x releases.
segment.target: If you specify only the /p option, the storage space estimations are created in the same manner as with USMT3.x releases.

segment.source: or /help
segment.target: or /help

segment.source: Displays Help at the command line.
segment.target: Displays Help at the command line.

segment.source: User Options
segment.target: User Options

segment.source: By default, all users are migrated.
segment.target: By default, all users are migrated.

segment.source: The only way to specify which users to include and exclude is by using the following options.
segment.target: The only way to specify which users to include and exclude is by using the following options.

segment.source: You cannot exclude users in the migration .xml files or using the Config.xml file.
segment.target: You cannot exclude users in the migration .xml files or using the Config.xml file.

segment.source: For more information, see Identify Users and Migrate User Accounts.
segment.target: For more information, see Identify Users and Migrate User Accounts.

segment.source: Command-Line Option
segment.target: Command-Line Option

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: all
segment.target: all

segment.source: Migrates all of the users on the computer.
segment.target: Migrates all of the users on the computer.

segment.source: USMT migrates all user accounts on the computer, unless you specifically exclude an account with either the /ue or /uel options.
segment.target: USMT migrates all user accounts on the computer, unless you specifically exclude an account with either the /ue or /uel options.

segment.source: For this reason, you do not need to specify this option on the command line.
segment.target: For this reason, you do not need to specify this option on the command line.

segment.source: However, if you choose to specify the /all option, you cannot also use the /ui, /ue or /uel options.
segment.target: However, if you choose to specify the /all option, you cannot also use the /ui, /ue or /uel options.

segment.source: ui:DomainNameUserName
segment.target: ui:DomainNameUserName

segment.source: or
segment.target: or

segment.source: ui:ComputerNameLocalUserName
segment.target: ui:ComputerNameLocalUserName

segment.source: (User include)
segment.target: (User include)

segment.source: Migrates the specified users.
segment.target: Migrates the specified users.

segment.source: By default, all users are included in the migration.
segment.target: By default, all users are included in the migration.

segment.source: Therefore, this option is helpful only when used with the /ue or /uel options.
segment.target: Therefore, this option is helpful only when used with the /ue or /uel options.

segment.source: You can specify multiple /ui options, but you cannot use the /ui option with the /all option.
segment.target: You can specify multiple /ui options, but you cannot use the /ui option with the /all option.

segment.source: DomainName and UserName can contain the asterisk (*) wildcard character.
segment.target: DomainName and UserName can contain the asterisk (*) wildcard character.

segment.source: When you specify a user name that contains spaces, you will need to surround it with quotation marks.
segment.target: When you specify a user name that contains spaces, you will need to surround it with quotation marks.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If a user is specified for inclusion with the /ui option, and also is specified to be excluded with either the /ue or /uel options, the user will be included in the migration.
segment.target: If a user is specified for inclusion with the /ui option, and also is specified to be excluded with either the /ue or /uel options, the user will be included in the migration.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: To include only User2 from the Fabrikam domain, type:
segment.target: To include only User2 from the Fabrikam domain, type:

segment.source: To migrate all users from the Fabrikam domain, and only the user accounts from other domains that have been active or otherwise modified in the last 30 days, type:
segment.target: To migrate all users from the Fabrikam domain, and only the user accounts from other domains that have been active or otherwise modified in the last 30 days, type:

segment.source: In this example, a user account from the Contoso domain that was last modified 2 months ago will not be migrated.
segment.target: In this example, a user account from the Contoso domain that was last modified 2 months ago will not be migrated.

segment.source: For more examples, see the descriptions of the /ue and /ui options in this table.
segment.target: For more examples, see the descriptions of the /ue and /ui options in this table.

segment.source: uel:NumberOfDays
segment.target: uel:NumberOfDays

segment.source: or
segment.target: or

segment.source: uel:YYYY/MM/DD
segment.target: uel:YYYY/MM/DD

segment.source: or
segment.target: or

segment.source: /uel:0
segment.target: /uel:0

segment.source: (User exclude based on last logon)
segment.target: (User exclude based on last logon)

segment.source: Migrates the users that logged onto the source computer within the specified time period, based on the Last Modified date of the Ntuser.dat file on the source computer.
segment.target: Migrates the users that logged onto the source computer within the specified time period, based on the Last Modified date of the Ntuser.dat file on the source computer.

segment.source: The /uel option acts as an include rule.
segment.target: The /uel option acts as an include rule.

segment.source: For example, the /uel:30 option migrates users who logged on, or whose account was modified, within the last 30 days from the date when the ScanState command is run.
segment.target: For example, the /uel:30 option migrates users who logged on, or whose account was modified, within the last 30 days from the date when the ScanState command is run.

segment.source: You can specify a number of days or you can specify a date.
segment.target: You can specify a number of days or you can specify a date.

segment.source: You cannot use this option with the /all option.
segment.target: You cannot use this option with the /all option.

segment.source: USMT retrieves the last logon information from the local computer, so the computer does not need to be connected to the network when you run this option.
segment.target: USMT retrieves the last logon information from the local computer, so the computer does not need to be connected to the network when you run this option.

segment.source: In addition, if a domain user has logged onto another computer, that logon instance is not considered by USMT.
segment.target: In addition, if a domain user has logged onto another computer, that logon instance is not considered by USMT.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The /uel option is not valid in offline migrations.
segment.target: The /uel option is not valid in offline migrations.

segment.source: /uel:0 migrates any users who are currently logged on.
segment.target: /uel:0 migrates any users who are currently logged on.

segment.source: /uel:90 migrates users who have logged on, or whose accounts have been otherwise modified, within the last 90 days.
segment.target: /uel:90 migrates users who have logged on, or whose accounts have been otherwise modified, within the last 90 days.

segment.source: /uel:1 migrates users whose account has been modified within the last 24 hours.
segment.target: /uel:1 migrates users whose account has been modified within the last 24 hours.

segment.source: /uel:2002/1/15 migrates users who have logged on or been modified January 15, 2002 or afterwards.
segment.target: /uel:2002/1/15 migrates users who have logged on or been modified January 15, 2002 or afterwards.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: ue:DomainNameUserName
segment.target: ue:DomainNameUserName

segment.source: -or-
segment.target: -or-

segment.source: ue:ComputerNameLocalUserName
segment.target: ue:ComputerNameLocalUserName

segment.source: (User exclude)
segment.target: (User exclude)

segment.source: Excludes the specified users from the migration.
segment.target: Excludes the specified users from the migration.

segment.source: You can specify multiple /ue options.
segment.target: You can specify multiple /ue options.

segment.source: You cannot use this option with the /all option.
segment.target: You cannot use this option with the /all option.

segment.source: DomainName and UserName can contain the asterisk (*) wildcard character.
segment.target: DomainName and UserName can contain the asterisk (*) wildcard character.

segment.source: When you specify a user name that contains spaces, you need to surround it with quotation marks.
segment.target: When you specify a user name that contains spaces, you need to surround it with quotation marks.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: How to Use /ui and /ue
segment.target: How to Use /ui and /ue

segment.source: The following examples apply to both the /ui and /ue options.
segment.target: The following examples apply to both the /ui and /ue options.

segment.source: You can replace the /ue option with the /ui option to include, rather than exclude, the specified users.
segment.target: You can replace the /ue option with the /ui option to include, rather than exclude, the specified users.

segment.source: Behavior
segment.target: Behavior

segment.source: Command
segment.target: Command

segment.source: Exclude the user named User One in the Fabrikam domain.
segment.target: Exclude the user named User One in the Fabrikam domain.

segment.source: Exclude the user named User1 in the Fabrikam domain.
segment.target: Exclude the user named User1 in the Fabrikam domain.

segment.source: Exclude the local user named User1.
segment.target: Exclude the local user named User1.

segment.source: Exclude all domain users.
segment.target: Exclude all domain users.

segment.source: Exclude all local users.
segment.target: Exclude all local users.

segment.source: Exclude users in all domains named User1, User2, and so on.
segment.target: Exclude users in all domains named User1, User2, and so on.

segment.source: Using the Options Together
segment.target: Using the Options Together

segment.source: You can use the /uel, /ue and /ui options together to migrate only the users that you want migrated.
segment.target: You can use the /uel, /ue and /ui options together to migrate only the users that you want migrated.

segment.source: The /ui option has precedence over the /ue and /uel options.
segment.target: The /ui option has precedence over the /ue and /uel options.

segment.source: If a user is specified to be included using the /ui option, and also specified to be excluded using either the /ue or /uel options, the user will be included in the migration.
segment.target: If a user is specified to be included using the /ui option, and also specified to be excluded using either the /ue or /uel options, the user will be included in the migration.

segment.source: For example, if you specify , then User1 will be migrated, because the /ui option takes precedence over the /ue option.
segment.target: For example, if you specify , then User1 will be migrated, because the /ui option takes precedence over the /ue option.

segment.source: The /uel option takes precedence over the /ue option.
segment.target: The /uel option takes precedence over the /ue option.

segment.source: If a user has logged on within the specified time period set by the /uel option, that user’s profile will be migrated even if they are excluded by using the /ue option.
segment.target: If a user has logged on within the specified time period set by the /uel option, that user’s profile will be migrated even if they are excluded by using the /ue option.

segment.source: For example, if you specify , the User1 will be migrated if they have logged on to the computer within the last 14 days.
segment.target: For example, if you specify , the User1 will be migrated if they have logged on to the computer within the last 14 days.

segment.source: Behavior
segment.target: Behavior

segment.source: Command
segment.target: Command

segment.source: Include only User2 from the Fabrikam domain and exclude all other users.
segment.target: Include only User2 from the Fabrikam domain and exclude all other users.

segment.source: Include only the local user named User1 and exclude all other users.
segment.target: Include only the local user named User1 and exclude all other users.

segment.source: Include only the domain users from Contoso, except Contoso\User1.
segment.target: Include only the domain users from Contoso, except Contoso\User1.

segment.source: This behavior cannot be completed using a single command.
segment.target: This behavior cannot be completed using a single command.

segment.source: Instead, to migrate this set of users, you will need to specify the following:
segment.target: Instead, to migrate this set of users, you will need to specify the following:

segment.source: On the ScanState command line, type:
segment.target: On the ScanState command line, type:

segment.source: On the LoadState command line, type:
segment.target: On the LoadState command line, type:

segment.source: Include only local (non-domain) users.
segment.target: Include only local (non-domain) users.

segment.source: Encrypted File Options
segment.target: Encrypted File Options

segment.source: You can use the following options to migrate encrypted files.
segment.target: You can use the following options to migrate encrypted files.

segment.source: In all cases, by default, USMT fails if an encrypted file is found unless you specify an /efs option.
segment.target: In all cases, by default, USMT fails if an encrypted file is found unless you specify an /efs option.

segment.source: To migrate encrypted files, you must change the default behavior.
segment.target: To migrate encrypted files, you must change the default behavior.

segment.source: For more information, see Migrate EFS Files and Certificates.
segment.target: For more information, see Migrate EFS Files and Certificates.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: EFS certificates will be migrated automatically when migrating to Windows 7, Windows 8 or Windows 10.
segment.target: EFS certificates will be migrated automatically when migrating to Windows 7, Windows 8 or Windows 10.

segment.source: Therefore, you should specify the /efs:copyraw option with the ScanState command to migrate the encrypted files
segment.target: Therefore, you should specify the /efs:copyraw option with the ScanState command to migrate the encrypted files

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: Take caution when migrating encrypted files.
segment.target: Take caution when migrating encrypted files.

segment.source: If you migrate an encrypted file without also migrating the certificate, end users will not be able to access the file after the migration.
segment.target: If you migrate an encrypted file without also migrating the certificate, end users will not be able to access the file after the migration.

segment.source: Command-Line Option
segment.target: Command-Line Option

segment.source: Explanation
segment.target: Explanation

segment.source: /efs:hardlink
segment.target: /efs:hardlink

segment.source: Creates a hard link to the EFS file instead of copying it.
segment.target: Creates a hard link to the EFS file instead of copying it.

segment.source: Use only with the /hardlink and the /nocompress options.
segment.target: Use only with the /hardlink and the /nocompress options.

segment.source: /efs:abort
segment.target: /efs:abort

segment.source: Causes the ScanState command to fail with an error code, if an Encrypting File System (EFS) file is found on the source computer.
segment.target: Causes the ScanState command to fail with an error code, if an Encrypting File System (EFS) file is found on the source computer.

segment.source: Enabled by default.
segment.target: Enabled by default.

segment.source: /efs:skip
segment.target: /efs:skip

segment.source: Causes the ScanState command to ignore EFS files.
segment.target: Causes the ScanState command to ignore EFS files.

segment.source: efs:decryptcopy
segment.target: efs:decryptcopy

segment.source: Causes the ScanState command to decrypt the file, if possible, before saving it to the migration store, and to fail if the file cannot be decrypted.
segment.target: Causes the ScanState command to decrypt the file, if possible, before saving it to the migration store, and to fail if the file cannot be decrypted.

segment.source: If the ScanState command succeeds, the file will be unencrypted in the migration store, and once you run the LoadState command, the file will be copied to the destination computer.
segment.target: If the ScanState command succeeds, the file will be unencrypted in the migration store, and once you run the LoadState command, the file will be copied to the destination computer.

segment.source: /efs:copyraw
segment.target: /efs:copyraw

segment.source: Causes the ScanState command to copy the files in the encrypted format.
segment.target: Causes the ScanState command to copy the files in the encrypted format.

segment.source: The files will be inaccessible on the destination computer until the EFS certificates are migrated.
segment.target: The files will be inaccessible on the destination computer until the EFS certificates are migrated.

segment.source: EFS certificates will be automatically migrated; however, by default USMT fails if an encrypted file is found, unless you specify an /efs option.
segment.target: EFS certificates will be automatically migrated; however, by default USMT fails if an encrypted file is found, unless you specify an /efs option.

segment.source: Therefore you should specify the /efs:copyraw option with the ScanState command to migrate the encrypted file.
segment.target: Therefore you should specify the /efs:copyraw option with the ScanState command to migrate the encrypted file.

segment.source: Then, when you run the LoadState command, the encrypted file and the EFS certificate will be automatically migrated.
segment.target: Then, when you run the LoadState command, the encrypted file and the EFS certificate will be automatically migrated.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: All files must be encrypted if the parent folder is encrypted.
segment.target: All files must be encrypted if the parent folder is encrypted.

segment.source: If the encryption attribute on a file inside an encrypted folder has been removed, the file will be encrypted during the migration using the credentials of the account used to run the LoadState tool.
segment.target: If the encryption attribute on a file inside an encrypted folder has been removed, the file will be encrypted during the migration using the credentials of the account used to run the LoadState tool.

segment.source: For more information, see Migrate EFS Files and Certificates.
segment.target: For more information, see Migrate EFS Files and Certificates.

segment.source: Incompatible Command-Line Options
segment.target: Incompatible Command-Line Options

segment.source: The following table indicates which command-line options are not compatible with the ScanState command.
segment.target: The following table indicates which command-line options are not compatible with the ScanState command.

segment.source: If the table entry for a particular combination is blank, the options are compatible and you can use them together.
segment.target: If the table entry for a particular combination is blank, the options are compatible and you can use them together.

segment.source: The X symbol means that the options are not compatible.
segment.target: The X symbol means that the options are not compatible.

segment.source: For example, you cannot use the /nocompress option with the /encrypt option.
segment.target: For example, you cannot use the /nocompress option with the /encrypt option.
